Suppose, for instance, a boy from the Orkney or Shetland Islands is put into the Naval Reserve and is sent to Portsmouth to be trained. At Portsmouth he hears that his mother is being taken into court for the rent. Are you going to pay that boy's fare and provide him with any assistance in court in order to protect his interests?
Are you going to provide his mother with legal assistance?

We must ask these questions. These are no mere forecasts of gloom. These are not criticisms of the Government. They are factual questions to which we demand specific replies-There is another thing. Is there an appeal from the decision of the court supposing a magistrate gives a judgment which is obviously harsh and unconscionable? I understand the hon. and learned Gentleman opposite to say that there is. It is a marvellous thing to get one of them to speak. I gather from the Solicitor-General that there is, but apparently his view is not corroborated by the Attorney-General. Then I would like to ask, how far does this circle of moratorium extend?
We understand that the boy who has a bicycle is protected in relation to his payments on the bicycle and that the bicycle cannot be seized. What about the agent who has sold him the bicycle? Can he plead that he cannot pay the manufacturer, because the boy who has been conscripted, has not paid him? Suppose the manufacturer has 1,000 bicycles out. Can he plead in the bankruptcy court that he cannot go bankrupt because the agent who sold them has been called up?
Here is another question: Suppose a man is in a building society. We know that he cannot pay his instalments, that his period of instalments can be prolonged, and that he remains in possession of his house, but suppose he is so much in debt when he has finished his service that he cannot pay his next instalment. What will happen then? We have a right to know, because we have been told that it is urgent to pass these things because the boys must know where they stand. Finally, the Prime Minister told us that he was pursuing this procedure, in defiance of the censure of the Lord Chancellor, in order to hear what we had to say, and more particularly to see how the thing worked out in practice. Will the Minister of Health undertake to ask every public assistance committee to report the cases of militiamen's dependants that come before them; will the Attorney-General ask every county court to report every case connected with a militiaman that comes to court; and will other Departments similarly concerned see that, in a scientific way, the evidence is collected and then laid before this House? Our great difficulty is that we get letters mentioning difficulties, and we bring them forward in all good faith and ask questions about them, and we are told that they are being investigated. It is a thoroughly unsatisfactory way of clearing up hardships, if hardships exist.
The right hon. Gentleman the Prime Minister has come forward voluntarily and said, "I must ask you to pass these Regulations, and we will amend them, because they are bad." [Interruption.] Did I understand the President of the Board of Trade to say "No"? The Lord Chancellor says "Yes, they are bad," so what will he do about it? I have made a practical suggestion in order to get hardships cleared up. Will the right hon. Gentleman undertake that some
such means will be set in motion, so that we shall have reliable information, in order that all of us may know whether or not these things are inflicting hardship? Is that an unreasonable thing to ask? Why cannot we have this information laid before us? If we do, we shall be able to see what amendments must be made in the Regulations. I make these practical suggestions and put these few questions, and I would ask the right hon. Gentleman whether he will kindly reply to them, and if he will not take it amiss, I will then move the Amendment that stands in our name.

speech.speakername: The Secretary of State for War (Mr. Hore-Belisha)
speech.p: The right hon. Gentleman the Member for Gorton (Mr. Benn) is pleased with the "cloud of witnesses" which he has brought forward, and he has said that if I do not satisfactorily answer his questions, he intends to put them to others of my colleagues. I will endeavour to answer the questions which he has put. Some of them, of course, were irrelevant to the draft Orders-in-Council which we are discussing, as, for instance, whether a. militiaman who was due to go to a university would ante-date or postpone his period of training. That is the question which is now being discussed between the Minister of Labour, the War Office, the headmasters of schools and the universities in an endeavour to come to an arrangement which will be most suited to the interests of the militiamen. The right hon. Gentleman next asked what treatment would be meted out to those militiamen who were injured in the course of their service. They will, of course, come for pension if disabled under exactly the same procedure as Regular soldiers. He asked another question, which was not precisely related to these Orders, but which may be considered to be pertinent— whether the Government Departments concerned would keep a watch upon the fortunes of militiamen to see to what extent they or their families were put to privation, or were compelled to go before the courts, and I take it in other respects also. I can assure the right hon. Gentleman that as this is the first time, at any rate in peace, that such an experiment has been undertaken, all Government Departments will follow the fortunes of the militiamen and of their families with the very greatest interest.

That was not the question. What I asked was this. Will the courts and the public assistance committees and other bodies be asked to make returns of cases of militiamen that come before them, and will those returns be laid before the House?

I ask the right hon. Gentleman to believe that the Government are interested in these militiamen, and will pursue their own way of getting this information, but we shall obtain all necessary information, though I cannot say exactly in what form. If the right hon. Gentleman is not satisfied with such information as he can procure by Question and Answer, it will be open to him to move for a return.
Yes, and the Orders will be passed, but my chance of getting anything done will be gone.

The right hon. Gentleman need not approach the matter with venom, but I hope he will do so with the same good humour which characterised the greater part of his speech. He asked me other questions, the answer to which I shall endeavour to incorporate in the general sequence of my speech. The Government realise, of course, that the House is placed in a certain difficulty by this procedure, but events are moving with great speed, and they have compelled us to act in the introduction of the Bills from which the Orders-in-Council arise, more summarily than we should otherwise have done. It was only on 26th April that the prospective introduction of these two Bills, the Military Training Bill and the Reserve Forces Bill, was announced. It was only just before Whitsun that these Bills were passed. Reservists have already returned to the Colours, and the militiamen will be coming up on 15th July. Hence it was necessary to resort to the procedure which was authorised by the House, and I am sure the House will realise that much labour and reflection have been involved in the preparation of these Orders.
I entered upon this Debate with some apprehension, because it was being suggested, as I understood it, that something was being taken away from the militiamen and the Reservists, that the Government were about to do them some injury from which it was necessary that the House should protect them. In reply
to the hon. Member for West Waltham-stow (Mr. McEntee), I can give the positive assurance that no right at present enjoyed by a militiaman or Reservist is being taken away. No one who comes under either of these two Measures is going to be any the worse off in respect of his rights. We have already settled the age at which the Militia shall be called up. We chose the age of 20 because it was the age at which a man can serve with the minimum of hardship to himself. That in itself saves him from many disabilities which he would incur, perhaps, if he were summoned to the Colours at a later age. We have settled his pay, we have settled his allowances, and it is therefore quite untrue to suggest, as has been suggested from the other side of the House, that the Government are not paying a penny towards the Militia. That has been said— that the Government are doing nothing at all. In addition to pay and allowances for wives and dependants we have established, or are about to establish, a Military Service (Special Allowances) Committee, which can give assistance to a militiaman up to £ 2s a week in cash if he is suffering any hardship which he may be able to present to the Committee. That is not ungenerous treatment.
I asked the Chancellor of the Duchy whether rent was included. Could a militiaman apply to the special allowances committee for financial assistance on account of rent?

The White Paper speaks for itself in that respect when, after setting up the Committee, it states that it is to: consider applications for special monetary assistance from those who notwithstanding the special protection afforded by the Orders-in-Council made under the two Acts and any normal allowances which may be granted for families and dependants, are unable, by reason of undergoing a course of six months' training … or by reason of being called out for service under the Reserve and Auxiliary Forces Act, 1939, to meet their financial obligations, whereby serious hardship is caused. As to the circumstances in which they may be granted that assistance one is that they are unable by reason of their service to meet their financial obligations, whereby serious hardship is caused. Therefore, in a proper case the allow-
ances paid by this Committee could be in supplementation of rent.

In the case of a militiaman who is summoned to appear at court by a landlord for non-payment of rent— that is the kind of case it is expected those provisions will cover— could he, when a summons is issued against him or an order is given against him by the court— which is non-enforceable during the training period— could he apply to this Committee for a grant to enable him to meet his liability, and in those circumstances would the Committee make the grant?

The White Paper states after the paragraph which I have already read: For the purpose of deciding the measure of assistance all factors may be taken into consideration, including the special protection given under the Orders-in-Council made under the two Acts. That is to say, including the special provision as to rent. Therefore, I think the hon. Member is completely met.
In addition to these aids which I have already described, the militiaman's job is kept open for him at the expense of the employer, who is under a severe penalty if he does not take him back. Apart from all these protections, we have looked around to discover what other disabilities men called up for service under either of these Acts might be expected to suffer in order that we could mitigate these wherever reasonably possible. I think the House, before proceeding to a Division, should not consider what we are not doing but should consider what we are doing, and what we are doing I think the House must agree is quite considerable. The first and most obvious difficulty with which a militiaman is confronted is his position as a householder. I ask the House to consider how elaborately we have endeavoured to cover his position in that respect, and whether or not what we have tried to do is reasonable.
From what are you quoting?

I am going to quote from Article I of the Military Training Order. I do not think the provision of this Order has been completely apprehended in some quarters. The Article says: Where any judgment or order has been given or made by any court for the recovery
of possession of any premises of which a person was in occupation immediately before his period of training; or for the payment of any rent due … or for the payment of any money due under a mortgage … or for the payment of any debt incurred before the data specified no step shall, during the period of training of that person or within six months after the end thereof, be taken, by way of execution or otherwise, for the enforcement of the judgment or order except with the leave of the court. That is the first protection, that he remains in his house and, except with the leave of the court, which has to regard all the circumstances of the case, he cannot be dislodged. It surely would not be suggested that we should give the same protection in circumstances in which it would be abused. Hence the court must intervene. I take it that some of these men will be moderately well off. If a rich man is occupying a house it would not be reasonable that he should refrain from paying the rent due to his landlord, and hence it is for the court to determine whether or not it is fair that the landlord should be able to exact his rent. During this same period no remedy which may be available to any person for obtaining such possession or payment shall be exercised except with the leave of the court. That includes rent and money due under mortgages.
Supposing subsequently to this period the man still remains in a difficulty on return to his house or premises and cannot then pay his rent— the same applies to building societies— then he comes under Article 2 (1), which is enduring for all time, and if the person against whom a judgment or order was given for recovery of possession of the property or for the payment of any money or the enforcement of his security satisfies the court that by reason of circumstances directly or indirectly attributable to any person being or having been a person under training it is necessary for the avoidance of hardship that execution of the judgment or order should be stayed or provision made for payment by instalments of any money payable there under, the court may make such order as it thinks just. There is the man— this covers more than what I am going to say— who has paid no rent during his Militia service, and has accumulated a certain debt to his landlord and finds it difficult to discharge that debt at once
because he is not completely restored in earning capacity. He comes under Article 2, and he goes to the court, who can make any order it thinks fit, including an order for him to pay by instalments. Therefore, the man has a very extended protection for all time. It is for the court to decide —
But the court does not know these facts. The man himself is not legally defended; it may be that he is not there; how does the right hon. Gentleman know that the court will be fully informed?

That is another point, on which I shall say a word. The point I am making here is that very adequate protection is given to the man who is doing his service. It is for the court to decide what is his position, in relation, not only to the period during which he is on service, but for a period afterwards. I described it as being for all time, but, of course, it must be a reasonable period. [Interruption..] It must be remembered that this is after six months' service, and he will not require the whole of his life to discharge a debt which he may have accumulated in that period of six months. It will be for the court to decide.

Surely, that debt is incurred by his serving the State, and no man should be worse off for giving service to the State. Surely, any debts that he incurs in that period ought to be discharged by the State?
When we were dealing with the burden to be put on employers, I did not notice the same attitude—
The debt should be discharged by you, not by the employer.

If that be the universal principle, it should apply to employers also. Hon. Members opposite wished to put a greater burden on employers in connection with this Act, and we accepted their position. The protection in the Article relates, not only to the militiaman, but to any other person, and, just as the sins of the fathers are, I under stand, visited on the second and third generation—
You must be the third.
So the man who is put in a difficulty by not receiving his rent can go to the court for exactly the same protection as the militiaman.
In the event of the landlord not receiving his rent, and therefore not paying the rates, the local authority can levy distress without resort to the courts. Is that position covered?
That matter is completely covered by Article 2 (2). Just as with rents, so with debts.

May I ask the Minister whether he is aware what it means to a militiaman if he has to pay rent and on top of rent to pay instalments on a debt? Can he give us a case where they would take over an industry from an employer for six months and leave the employer with debt as a result of taking over?

It is the safeguards to the militiaman in that respect which I have been endeavouring to describe to the House. He may go to the Special Committee, which has power to assist him where circumstances warrant. He has allowances for his dependants. In addition he need not pay any rent during his period of service, and, if it be not convenient, for another six months, and if, even after that, he still finds himself in difficulty, the court may make an arrangement that he may pay by instalments. Those are very adequate provisions. As I was about to say when the hon. Member intervened, just as with rent, so with debts. If the militiaman has given some security for a debt before 15th June, the date of these Orders, the security cannot be disposed of without the leave of the court. All those provisions cover the militiaman, as I have said, not only during his period of service but for six months after, and if necessary, even further.
Surely he can only apply to a hardship committee while he is serving as a militiaman?
I have said that the militiaman can go to this committee. I was talking about the militiaman. I hope that the right hon. Gentleman will not try to misunderstand me.
Hon. Members have put a lot of questions to the Minister. They have asked him to reply and now that he is replying they should give him an opportunity to do so.
The right hon. Gentleman said, speaking about the militiaman, that he was covered for his period of training and for six months after. That is not so.

That is correct in relation to the provisions which I have described and which I have actually read out to the House. He is covered for six months and for an equivalent period of six months after, and I said that if he was still in a difficulty he can go to the court, which can give him some further protection. I have stated the position accurately. If his house was in process of being purchased through a building society, the period of his service is void and he pays nothing during that period, and, therefore, the extent of the time over which the purchase was being made is advanced by a further six months.
Will the right hon. Gentleman answer the question which I put to him? It is obvious that we must ask questions. I do not know whether the right hon. Gentleman was going to deal with it.

I thought I had answered it once, but I will answer it again, although, if the hon. Gentleman does not mind, not precisely at this point. I was just rehearsing what we were in fact doing for the militiaman, because we have heard a great deal about what we are not doing. The provisions of Sub section 2 (2) —

I thought the right hon. Gentleman was dealing with Article 3. I was referring to the time when the returned militiaman is called upon to pay the first instalment to the building society. I pointed out that if he returned from training on, say, the 1st of the month, and the first repayment was due on the 5th, he would not have time to gather the necessary funds.

I think I mentioned in passing just now that if he were unable to make the repayment, he could, under Article 2 (2), get an arrangement made by the court, under which process could not be taken against him.
I asked if the right hon. Gentleman could tell me the meaning of "partly dependent" in Article 1 (3), and also of the expression "licence of any other person."

I assure the hon. Member that I shall try to answer all these questions, though I cannot answer them all at once. The point is not exactly germane, but what it applies to is the case of a person who is a lodger in a house or any dwelling as part of his contract of service, such as a, gardener or an agricultural labourer. That is the kind of situation that Article I (3) envisages.
If the mother of a militiaman rents a house, she may be evicted from the house. Is there any protection for her?

The Sub-section says: Where a person was immediately before the beginning of his period of training residing in a dwelling-house, or part of a dwelling-house, with any person wholly or partly dependent on him"— this I take to include the mother in the question put by the hon. Member— and the premises were occupied by them or any of them by the licence of any other person — this covers the case of a lodger— no right of that other person to terminate the licence shall be exercised during the period of training, or within six months after the end thereof, except with the leave of the High Court or the county court. That, I think, is self-explanatory.

In the case I have mentioned the mother would not be a lodger. She would be the person renting the premises. If the answer of the Minister is right, the mother in that case would not be protected. She would be protected only if she and her son were lodgers in the house.

If she be not completely covered in the circumstances described by the hon. Member under that Sub-section, she is covered by Sub-section (1) or (2) of Article 2, as the case may be, and she still has the claim to protection that I have already described. It is a very wide shelter that we are endeavouring to give, covering not only the militiaman but his relations and dependants and anyone affected, directly or indirectly, by the period of service that he has to undergo. I would like to pass to another kind of protection while we are dealing with this matter.

I want to ask the Minister a question about the Small
Dwellings (Acquisition) Act. A militiaman who has borrowed £ 500 under the Small Dwellings (Acquisition) Act has to pay £ 2 6s. 8d. per month, and at the end of 12 months may owe something like £ 28. How do you propose to meet him, as there is nothing here referring to the Small Dwellings (Acquisition) Act?
I have a note down to answer that question, but what makes it so difficult is that I am required to answer all these questions simultaneously.
It comes in this section.

If the hon. Gentleman is asking whether the man can be evicted, he is covered. He cannot be evicted. If he is asking whether the local authority is prepared to treat him in the same way as the building society is going to treat him under this Order, that matter, I am informed by my right hon. Friend the Minister of Health, will, on the suggestion made by the hon. Gentleman this afternoon, be taken up with the local authorities.
Thank you.

We also cover the persons affected under the Insurance Acts. I have been asked by several speakers, including the hon. Gentleman the Member for Gorbals (Mr. Buchanan), why we only cover persons in insurable occupations. Everyone who is normally in an insurable occupation will be given his 30 contributions and will be covered. It is not reasonable under the present Order-in-Council to include militiamen not normally in insurable occupations. For instance, teachers and civil servants may not be in insurable occupations. The position is quite different as regards the Regular soldier, and it was suggested that he should be treated on the same basis as the Regular soldier. The Regular soldier adopts the Army as a career for a long period of years, and the State is his employer in the course of that career. The State accordingly covers him for insurance, but this Act does not propose to change, either for better or for worse, the status of those who are called up under the Military Training Act. The same applies to Reservists. Those who are already normally in insurable occupations and have their stamps will have their stamps paid for during their Reserve service, and if they are not normally in insurable occupations this course will not be followed.

The Secretary of State for War has only told me that teachers do not need it, but he has not answered the question why the man who has been unemployed before joining and has lost his insurance status should not be allowed to resume his status after he had served for six months by being credited with 30 stamps. He has not really been unemployed during that period, and, therefore, why should he not be credited with them? Why should not a man who has had a small business, like that of selling coal, and has lost it owing to having been called upon to serve, at least get unemployment benefit? I am asking a question, to which I should like an answer.
I have endeavoured to answer.
You spoke only of teachers.

I said that the draft Orders would not change the status of those called to the Militia, either for better or for worse; that if they normally were in an insurable occupation they would remain so. I say also that if they were normally in insurable work but on the Unemployment Assistance Board before they went to do their training they will finish their training and pass straight on to statutory benefit.
I know that.
The test is whether they were normally in an insurable occupation, and, even if they were under the Unemployment Assistance Board, that will remain the determining factor.

The Prime Minister told us to-day that we could put reasonable suggestions before the House. I am doing that. Here is a lad who has never worked. He has never had a chance of work, and he is in a distressed area. He has 26 weeks with the Army. Why-should he not be credited with 30 stamps? Why cannot he get that? That is the decent thing to do.

I have endeavoured to answer that point but evidently not to the satisfaction of the hon. Member. I said that we cannot make a general provision of this kind which would affect militiamen in work deliberately excluded from the Unemployment Insurance Scheme, and that if this were done the Unemployment Insurance Act ought itself to be amended.
The right hon. Gentleman is not saying that he has not the power.
I am not saying that I have not the power. I am saying what the facts may be.

The right hon. Gentleman said that these draft Orders will not alter the status of anybody. The plain fact is that they will very seriously alter the status of a large number of people. I will give a case that has come to my attention. A young fellow who has earned a living on a greengrocer's round, with a barrow and pony, kept his widowed mother. He goes into the Militia. At the end of six months his job is gone. He has to make another start in life. If he had 30 stamps on his card he could come out and get an occupation as an employed person. The status of that man is being altered and very great harm is being done.
If he comes straight into an insured occupation he will be covered by virtue of that occupation. Nobody would assert that he would be any worse off. [Interruption.]
Of course he is.
He is worse off. He has lost his business.

Does the right hon. Gentleman not realise that in this case the man when he comes back comes to the Poor Law relief, because he has no job? He has lost his benefit. Surely, his status has been made worse when he has to go to the Poor Law relief after having had a business of his own?

Having dealt with the unemployment side in his own way, will the right hon. Gentleman tell me in regard to National Health Insurance whether the qualifying stamps have to be real stamps or franks? I am anxious to know what is the status of an insured person who is unemployed and who is still continued in insurance by an approved society? Will the approved society be credited with 36 or 30 stamps in regard to that individual?
Anyone who is insured will remain insured, as his stamps will be provided for him.

The right hon. Gentleman has not understood my point. An approved society is carrying on a business with regard to persons who are insured members; it is contributing a cer-
tain portion to the State. I want to know whether the State, in regard to the 26 weeks Army employment, is going to give money, not stamps, to the society? Is there to be a State contribution to an approved society which is carrying the liability of a militiaman.
He is completely covered. If the hon. Member wants an answer to his question he will find it on page 2.

With due respect, the right hon. Gentleman is referring me to Articles 9 and 10, whose purpose is to secure to the militiamen who are insured under National Health Insurance that they will be insured during their period of training for National Health purposes and for contributory pension purposes. I know that they will be covered as insured members, but what I want to know is, will the approved society get a State contribution in respect of the 26 weeks?
Yes, Sir. He is covered in the same way as the Regular soldier.

I should like an answer to the case I put. A man has a little business. It will not be there when he comes back. Will not the right hon. Gentleman give that man a start in the insurance world by giving him 30 stamps?
I have endeavoured to answer the point.

I do not think the right hon. Gentleman has answered my question, which I put quite respectfully. Does he really mean that the operation of this new military system will involve ruination for that man and for his widowed mother?

I agree that the hon. Member put his question respectfully, and I have endeavoured to answer it respectfully. It is always possible to put a case in a form which harrows the feelings. The hon. Member said that the man has a horse and cart, and also a: widowed mother. [Interruption.] It may not be acceptable to the hon. Gentleman, but at any rate he will agree that I have answered the question.
You have told him "No."

I have. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for Gorton said that Lord Chancellors are exalted personages who never make any direct statement. For instance, they would have said of the right hon. Gentleman's speech that it was not without humour, rather than that it was with humour. Not being a Lord Chancellor, I have given a direct answer of "No." It appears to be unclear to the hon. Member. [Interruption.]
Hon. Members are now reducing the Debate to a farce.
The last thing I want to do, Sir, is to make the Debate ridiculous. You have never before had occasion to say a word of reproach to me —
I was not referring to the hon. Member, but to the general trend of the Debate.

May I put a further point? The Minister seemed to suggest that the case I put was a fictitious one. I assure him that it is not. Will he, at least, give me this undertaking, that if I give him the name and address of this young militiaman, he will look into it in order to see whether anything can be done to help him?
I will give two more.
I will give two or three.

I am very glad that the hon. Member has addressed to me a question to which I can give a satisfactory answer. I shall be most grateful if he will send me particulars of the case, and I will look into it with the greatest care.
What can you do?

When I see the case, I shall be able to say. Apart from the rights which the man may have under the State insurance schemes, he may also have certain rights under the superannuation schemes of local authorities, and these, as the House is well aware, are maintained for him, although he makes no contribution during his period of service. I was asked whether there would be any charge upon the ratepayers in respect of this provision. Any charge that may fall upon the ratepayers will be very small, because I am informed that the numbers affected in the case of any particular authority are not great, and that the actuarial stability of the schemes will not be affected. Then there is another class
of case, that is, rights which the man has chosen to acquire, such as either industrial insurance or life insurance rights. Here, as hon. Members will recall, the principle, briefly, is that if the policy was entered into before 15th June, the policy-holder is allowed a period of relief equal to twice his period of service, followed by a period of grace equal to his period of service, during which any arrears of premium falling due' during the period of relief shall be paid up without interest.
That is an endeavour to protect the men reasonably, but it has given rise to some questions. The right hon. Gentleman the Member for West Stirling (Mr. Johnston) asked why, if before the end of the period of grace we only deducted the arrears from the claim, if the claim arose after the period of grace the amount of the policy was reduced by multiplying the arrears by the factor referred to in the Schedule. We did make a distinction between these two periods, because if the claim arose during the period of grace, which is equal to half the period of relief, that man was intended to have the benefit, but if he had not discharged any part of his obligation during that period, it was not reasonable' to continue to give him the same treatment thereafter. I do regard that as satisfactory because, as I have said, the period of relief plus the period of grace is a considerable one. There are three equal periods. There is the period of service; there is the corresponding period afterwards, and these two periods together are called the period of relief. Then there is a further period of equal extent, which is the period of grace. That gives the militiaman a very great opportunity, and it is a proposal to which the insurance companies have taken some exception.
The hon. Member for East Aberdeen (Mr. Boothby), speaking the mind of the life insurance companies, said he accepted this provision as being entirely reasonable, as regards the Militia, but that he did not take quite the same view about extending these privileges to Reservists and Territorials. These fears are aroused, perhaps, by a misconception of the Government's intention. I agree that the burden would fall very hardly upon insurance companies, if we were continually calling up Reservists and Territorials for very long periods. Naturally, if we were doing that, it would be almost a state
of war, when all these provisions would have to be revised and it would be necessary to look into all the obligations of public and private bodies.
Can my right hon. Friend give an undertaking that in the event of war or a condition approaching war, the whole of these provisions would be revised by the Government?

Yes, it was our intention to do so in the event of war. I am not sure of what is meant by "a condition approaching war." That might depend upon the point of view. But if war conditions prevailed, it would be the Government's intention to revise these provisions. I hope the insurance companies will accept this liability, having regard to the circumstances in which it is being put upon them, and on the understanding that it is not the Government's intention to be continually calling up these people during the three years duration of the Act.
I was asked other questions in regard to insurance and I do not pretend that I shall answer every one of them but there is one which created some curiosity and with which I shall deal. I was asked why the limit of £25 had been fixed on the annual premiums of the policies entitled to relief. Of course it is an arbitrary figure. If we did not put in any figure at all the insurance companies would be worse off than they are. It is possible to evade it in the manner described by an hon. Member, but we saw no means of drawing any distinction between the man who could, presumably, afford to pay a large premium, and the man who could not, except this method. In adopting it I hope we have not erred and that in practice it will be found to work. There is another class of benefits— that is, the benefits which a man has earned by his own ability such as scholarships. Just before the right hon. Gentleman rose to sum up for the Opposition, I was asked a question regarding the postponement of a scholarship which a man enjoyed, so that he could carry it on after his period of service, much in the same way as he can carry on building society payments. I was asked whether in using the word "holder" of a scholarship or bursary, we intended to cover those who while they might have won scholarships could not technically be described as "holders." It was, of course, our intention to mean
the person who had won the scholarship, and I trust that the university authorities will look at the matter in that way, they being anxious, as we are, to treat the militiaman fairly.
The real case against these proposals was presented by the hon. Member for Seaham (Mr. Shinwell). He asked whether the Government were prepared to accept the suggestions which he was about to make or whether they were going to wait for clamour to impose the acceptance of those suggestions upon them. I do not think that the prospective militiaman is feeling that he is going to be treated unjustly, and, therefore, I do not think the dilemma is a true one. Nevertheless, I want to deal with the points raised by the hon. Gentleman. I made a full note; of what lie said, because, as always, it was interesting and vivid. Having told us his dilemma, he said, "Let us come to the facts of the situation." Now let us come to the facts as presented by the hon. Gentleman. He said that the Government were not giving anything away. I have already endeavoured to show that they are giving a great deal away, and the cost will amount to about £26,000,000 a year. The hon. Member took the hypothetical case of a man who went on training, and his wife or mother could not pay the rent. What was the landlord to do? He wants his rent, he issues a summons, and the man or his wife or mother is called before the court. Well, first of all, I do not think people will put into operation a legal process unless they think they have some very good ground upon which they can win their case, but I have, I think, already shown that that militiaman and his mother are already completely protected by the Clauses which I read at the beginning of my speech.
While I am dealing with this case, I am reminded that the hon. Member for Gorbals— I think it was—asked whether, if a militiaman were summoned to go before a court and the court was at some distance from his camp, his railway expenses would be met. I am grateful for that suggestion. I think now that it was the hon. Member for Hemsworth (Mr. G. Griffiths) who made it; he makes many good suggestions. While I trust there will not be many cases of militiamen being called before the courts, because I think the illustrations that have been given are quite exceptional, yet we would be pre-
pared to consider, in any suitable case, giving to the militiaman assistance.
Will the right hon. Gentleman give us a definite answer that he will pay this man's fare if he has to go 200 miles from his training camp to the court?

I have said that I will consider that matter. In the course of the Military Training Bill I gave several undertakings, every one of which I implemented. I could not give an answer in a general form. I must consider in what form it should be given, but I am sympathetic. Then the hon. Member for Gorbals expressed the fear that the protection sought to be afforded by the Orders in regard to the enforcement of civil liabilities would be nugatory, because he alleged that it was the practice of the Scottish courts of granting decrees against offenders more or less automatically, unless offenders appeared personally or by solicitor in their defence. The hon. Member, apparently, feared that the militiaman or other person might be unable effectively to claim protection. What I am informed is that certainly an initial order for payment or for recovery of possession of premises may be made without any question being raised as to the rights of protection afforded by the Orders, and perhaps in ignorance of the fact that such rights exist, but that no harm will be done because the creditor can make no use of the Order without a second application for leave to enforce it. I am told it would not be the practice in England to hear a case in the man's absence while in Scotland there will be this protection that an order would be of no effect unless the court granted the necessary confirmation.
Does that apply to dependants as well as to militiamen?
Yes, I so understand it.

The second point is that the small debts court, having granted a decree, that decree will become immediately operative against the man the moment that his training is finished, because having been given in his absence, it will become operative against him.

This applies to England as well as Scotland. I did answer
that question. That is the case under the second Article, with which I have dealt at some length and which is enduring.
Then I was asked why protection was given to the militiaman whereas it was not given to him if he joined the Regular Army. If a man adopts the Regular Army as a career it would not be reasonable to expect that all these provisions in this Order should apply to him, because presumably he would not be keeping on his premises and would not be an employé under local authorities, who wanted his superannuation rights safeguarded, and so forth. The hon. Member also asked if a hire-purchase trader was not to have an order of the court enforced against him, what about the manufacturer? If the hire-purchase trader inconveniences the manufacturer to such an extent that he is going bankrupt or otherwise wants the protection of the court, he, also, can have it in the manner which I have endeavoured to describe.
Several hon. Members have made the statement that if the allowances were adequate there would be no need for these Orders. These Orders are not necessarily concerned with allowances at all, but with the protection of certain rights, such as a man's superannuation rights, and so forth. Unless the allowances were to be adjusted to the man's exact expenditure in private life, I fail to see how he could necessarily meet all the obligations which would be covered here. I was asked whether, if the militiaman were in debt to his landlord, he could go to the Special Committee. The answer is "Yes"; I think I gave it earlier.
The hon. Gentleman liked the Special Committee, which, on a previous occasion he compared with the Military Services Civil Liabilities Committee. On that occasion, before we had decided on this procedure, he recommended that we should deal with these cases by a special committee analogous to the Military Services Civil Liabilities Committee. He now says that the £2 a week permitted to be given by our Special Committee is inadequate. He attacks the Government on that ground, and presumably, unless he has been convinced by my argument, he will vote against it In recommending this procedure to us he said that, when the Military Services Civil Liabilities Committee was in exist-
ence, there was a proviso that assistance would not be given for the discharge of ordinary debts— which he is recommending in his Amendment to-night— and there was a limitation on the amount of the obligation that could be accepted by the Government, so that no more than £ 2 a week could be granted. We were vrey much impressed by his suggestion, and we adopted the figure of £ 2 a week. It is very odd that, having accepted and in some respects excelled the hon. Gentleman's suggestion, we are charged with being niggardly and mean.

I am glad that the right hon. Gentleman and the Government were impressed by what I said, but he has forgotten that the Civil Liabilities Committee during the War, although it set a maximum of £ 2 a week, did not take into account the allowance, and, in particular, the grant was not conditional on the making of an allotment.

If an allotment is made, it is taken into account as being part of the sum. [Interruption.] I know that the hon. Gentleman will have some sort of answer, but I will read his next sentence: Do the Government contemplate anything like that figure, or are the men to depend on the 12s. a week for dependants? He will see that we are doing very much more for them than he anticipated on that occasion.

I will not say that the right hon. Gentleman is mispresenting me, but there is a misunderstanding. I mentioned the question of allotment and allowance because his scheme is conditional on the man making an allotment to his dependants, and, therefore, the allotment must be taken into account before the allowance can be paid. I agree that the £ 2 is based on the actual amount that I mentioned, but both the allowance and the allotment are now included in the maximum of £ 2.
Hon. Members opposite have asked whether the civil servants who receive their civil pay during Reserve and Territorial service

include temporary and unestablished civil servants. The answer is that they will be included. I hope the House will consider that the Government are behaving generously in that respect. The hon. Gentleman opposite said the Government were trying to get conscription on the cheap. I hope I have shown that, on the contrary, we are dealing with these men as we intended throughout to do, with generosity and justice.

I asked a very specific question with regard to this Order No. 6043. The last paragraph says: Provided that in the event of the applicant's death during service the grant may be continued for a period not exceeding four weeks. Supposing death is caused by an accident, does workmen's compensation or employers' liability operate?
I answered that. I said he came under the same code as the Regular soldier and got compensation exactly on that basis.

Then a mechanic joining under the conditions of the Military Service Act, 1920, 20 years of age, loses all benefit that he would have as a civilian in regard to workmen's compensation and employers' liability?
The treatment accorded to the soldier is better. That is an established fact.

I beg to move, in line I, to leave out from the word "That," to the end of the Question, and to add instead thereof: in view of the unprecedented demand made upon those to whom the Military Training Act applies, provision should be made, where hardship would otherwise occur, to enable them and their dependants to meet obligations already entered into, and this House, therefore, cannot approve an Order which merely provides for the possible postponement of their liabilities, leaving them, upon return to civil life, to face a load of debt.
Question put, "That the words proposed to be left out stand part of the Question."
The House divided: Ayes, 195; Noes, 127.
